description: Australia is the only nation where women buy more sex toys than men, according to research which involved 400,000 people from six nations including the UK, US, France and Germany.
title: Australian women buy more sex toys than men
title_page: Australian women buy more sex toys than men | Daily Mail Online
text:
Australia is the only nation where women buy more sex toys than men, according to new research.
In a survey of 400,000 people from Australia as well as Germany, Britain, France, Canada and America, retailer Lovehoney found women Down Under make up 52 per cent of the nation's sex toy buyers.
In France, meanwhile, 58.4 per cent of sex toy buyers were male, while in the UK the split between male and female purchasers was roughly 50/50.
Online sex toy retailer Lovehoney analysed 5 million sex toys, lingerie items, and bondage accessories that were sold to over a million people worldwide in 2016 (stock image)
Of the six countries studied, Australia was the only one where women buy more sex toys than men (stock image)
Brisbane residents bought the most sex toys in the Lucky Country - purchasing twice as many toys as those in Darwin and Hobart, according to the research
Sydney ranked at number four, with 8.3 sex toy purchases for every 1,000 people.
The research also showed that Australian shoppers are three times as likely than Americans to buy a school uniform outfit.
However, with a big chunk of those buying sexy school uniforms being engaged women, the retailer said it could be that theyâ€™re a staple favourite of the hen party scene as well as being for bedroom wear.
Australians living in state capitals buy six times more sex toys than people living in more rural areas (stock image)
When it comes to the most popular clothing purchase it appears the nations are more closely aligned.
More Australians, Americans and Brits sought suspenders over other items of intimate attire, according to the retailer.
Only Germans differed, with their most popular item of clothing shown to be a corset or bustier.
19 per cent of German shoppers also favoured G-strings and thongs.
